elements.text: [Part One]
A bell tolls, a crowd cheers.

Often have these bells peeled out the dread summons of disaster. Now, on this morning of Good Friday, how joyously beautiful is their tone as they tell us of rebellion ended! Of war terminated! Of peace restored! Now and henceforth, in truth, in reality, we are, we will be the United States!
Cheers with a few boos.
What good will Union do the working man? The blood of our fathers and brothers and sons spilled in the service of Union and what for? To keep us in the poorhouse, and give the slave a vote!
Come on, shut it.
No surrender! Never surrender! Get your hands off me.
2: Come on, sir, there are ladies present.
No surrender! Never surrender!
Well now, Officer Parker keeping order, I see.
Mister Booth, fresher than a tulip, considering the state you was in last evening.
The state you were in, my friend, it's a miracle you're upright.
I'll admit it is this lamp post doing the work.
Officer? Officer Parker?
Oh, hell.
: What is the meaning of this? An officer of the Law standing by while rowdies run amok on the streets of the Capital?
Miss Harris, I'd say fellows that shoot their mouths off on a day feelings are running so high deserve a little roughing.
Officer Parker!
All right, all right, I'll go and knock some sense into them. Good day to you both.
Good day, Mister Parker.
The lot of you, fall back.
Would you have me escort you to a less troublesome spot, Miss Harris, was it? It'd be my pleasure.
Every woman in Washington knows of your pleasure, Mister Booth. I shall be perfectly safe without your protection, thank you.
As you wish. Good day. I hope we'll meet again, ma'am.
Sir.

Let no form of passion, no feeling of revenge, intrude upon any heart. Let all strive for not merely legal but for real hearty impassioned oneness of Union throughout our broad land. Union of hearts, Union of hands, Union in all that is American. Union and liberty, one and inseparable!
Cheers.

Pops! Pops! Where are you, boy? I thought I told you to stick to the stage door like molasses. (sniff) Is that lavender. (bangs on door) Pops. Pops, you got a piece in that dressing room? I can smell her, Pops. Don't you deny it. Mister Wilde'll be here any minute, you dallying dolt, and a gentleman like Mister Wilde, he'll be straight on the first boat back to England if he thinks he's walked into some kind of a cat house. Now open up!
[OC]: Entrée.
But that ain't. Oh Lord. Mister Wilde!
Not a chance. Oscar Wilde was 1854-1900, and this is 1865 by the opening speech.
Mister Ford, I presume.
Henry Clay Ford, at your service. (cough) Phew, that is some scent, Mister Wilde.
Oscar, please. An infusion of lavender and bergamot. I find it soothes my nerves.
I guess it must be the latest thing in London, right? Just like you, Mister Wilde.
Just like me, Mister Ford.
Well, welcome to my theatre.
Your brother's theatre, I believe?
Sure, sure. How'd you get in here?
I was a little early. Your boy, Pops, showed me in here and made me very comfortable. He even made me tea, or some Atlantic variation thereof.
Some Atlantic variation thereof. (laughs) That, that'll be the famous Oscar Wilde wit.
Devastating, isn't it?
You know, I gotta tell you, that wit is gonna make you famous all across these new United States.
That's the plan, yes.

This play of yours, the Importance of Being Ernest. Have to admit, when it arrived I though something that big's only good for a door stop. But you know what, Mister Wilde? I started reading and by the end I was literally laughing my head off.
How distressing for you. (yawns) I wonder whether you'd mind
Oh, of course, of course. You're tired. I'm so sorry, Mister Wilde. I guess I'll leave you to it. You've had one heck of a journey, I expect.
Door closes.
You've no idea.
Ah! P G H Fender.
P G H who?
Hmm? Only the finest player ever to captain England. Oh, what a day that was. Summer of '23, or was it '24. Ow!
Are you all right down there?
Got him with a concealed googly for 3. He was so impressed he simply put down his weapon and applauded. Ow!
Oh, Doctor, what on Earth are you talking about?
Ow! Right, that does it. No, no, too purple. No.
Doctor!
Cricket, Doctor Smythe. Cricket.
Oh, cricket. How did we get on to cricket?
Ah ha! One moment. Percy George, you see. He was one of the true gentlemen of the game. There, that should do it.
Do what?
This.
Thump. The Tardis materialises.
Oh, scientific as ever, Doctor.
Naturally. It doesn't take any old thump, you know. Each strike precisely timed and weighted.
Ah, just like P G H.
Experience and knowledge, Evelyn, that's what counts.
Not to mention concealing your googlies.
Hmm. Well, well. Earth again.
You amaze me.
And the year, 1865. Ring any bells?
Leopold II was crowned King of the Belgians, the Matterhorn was climbed for the first time, Rudyard Kipling was born on the 30th of December, the Duke of Abercorn
Quiet sort of time, then. Let's take a look round, shall we?
Tardis door opens.
I thought you'd never ask.
Banging on door.
Pops? Is that you? Brother may be in Virginia, but don't think you can swing the lead with me.
Now, now, who have we here? Ah, I remember. Young Harry.
Henry. Mister Booth, sir. The big man, he's in Richmond.
Don't matter, junior. Where's Maisie?
Maisie?
Titian haired beauty, runs the box office.
Oh, she's off. Stomach cramps or something.
Oh well. She keeps my messages behind. Reckoned I'd check them in passing, if I may?
Oh, sure. Always a pleasure to see the most esteemed members of the local company.
Not so esteemed as Harry Hawk these days.
Ah, but he's a revelation (under next line) Because of the ... far and wide on the strength of
them notices, even General Grant is
What's this? (reading) My dear Mister Booth. Permit me to prevail upon the finest thespian in the district to read for an Englishman an extract from the greatest play. Grant? He's coming here?
With the President, tonight. Had the White House boy stop by first thing.
Well now.
Can you believe, the hero of Appomattox here at Fords?
And the President?
Mrs Lincoln too. Them over at Grovers is going to be sick.
This fellow Wilde wants me to read for him. He on the level?
Mister Wilde? Oh, a great man, straight as they come. Me and him, we're in collaboration.
Are you now?
Mind, he's resting now, in his dresser.
If he's as keen as all that, he'll meet me, junior.
You can find the way, Mister Booth?
There's not an inch of Fords that I don't know.
You give it all you got, Mister Booth.
Door opens.
What the devil are you
Are we doing in your office? Good question.
And how in the blue blazes did this blue box get in here with you?
Another good question. And good questions deserve good answers. Well, Evelyn?
I er. Oh dear. This doesn't get any easier, does it?
Knock on door.
[OC]: Wilde? It's Booth.
Ah, my protégé. Do come in.
Door opens.
My dear fellow, take a seat, do.
Curious atmosphere here.
Lavender and bergamot, yes.
No, something else.
Door closes.
Mister Booth.
What's in here?
My cabinet of curiosities.
Your what?
Curios. The clue's in the name. Mister Booth, you seem edgy.
These are strange days we're living through.
Ah yes, and a man of your sympathies needs to be careful, yes?
What do you know of my sympathies, sir? Speak, or let Mister Bowie's blade paint these walls in English rouge.
I was, I was referring to those platonic sympathies common in the brotherhood of actors, but tragically misunderstood in the wider world.
Wilde, I thought you knew my reputation. Bad Johnny Booth only has eyes for the ladies. My knife ain't for no fruit.
Speaking of fruit, would you care for a glass of elderberry cordial? A trifle tart on the tongue, but positively bursting with antioxidants.
Well, if you're imbibing yourself.
Bums up. Hmm, sublime. Drink, drink.
In a moment. Business first.
Of course. I'll come straight to the point, Mister Booth. I saw you last year in Boston.
Highlights from Shakespeare.
Indeed. That night I Knew I'd seen the finest actor on the American stage, a figure to rival any in the opposite continent. Keen, Beerbohm Tree, Olivier.
Olivier?

Perhaps I'm being a trifle previous. No matter. You get my gist? These are princes, my boy, proud princes. Some actors are little better than strolling psychopaths, but it comes to a very few to be great. And you, Mister Booth, you will walk amongst them.
You think so.
I know so. And that is why I've written a little piece with you in mind. Booth?
(sotto) I thought I heard something behind that curtain.
Behind the curtain? Are you sure? I don't see anything.
Made you look, though, didn't I?
Very convincing.
Mud in your eye, Wilde. Hmm, not bad. This piece, is it tragedy, comedy, what?
Comedy of a kind. The hero of the piece is a smart young man who calls himself Jack, but thinks himself Ernest.
(gasp) Burglars! Burglars and vagabonds.
Well, really. Do we look the type?
Well, if it's last night's takings your after, I've banked them already.
No, you haven't.
Hands off, Captain.
Doctor, actually. And believe it or not, we've no interest in your takings.
Hold up. Is that an English accent?
To your ears, maybe.
Of course! You're with him.
Him?
I don't Know why I didn't see it before. I thought Mister Wilde was dandy enough, but this fellow here, he takes the biscuit, eh, lady?
I beg your pardon?
Well, that coat may be all the thing in Piccadilly, son, but here in DC folks will take you for a theatrical.
Now look here.
Of course, that's exactly what you are, isn't it. Seeing as you're with Oscar Wilde.
Just because a person happens. Did he just say Oscar Wilde?
He did.
So, what's in the box, eh, Doc? More fancy costumes?
Er, yes, among other things. Evelyn, this is 1865. Oscar Wilde's not out of short trousers.
Yes, yes, obviously, but
Something's very wrong here. I can smell it.
Damn, but this thing's warm. How'd you get this through the door?
Oh, secrets of the trade, Mister er
Ford, isn't it?
The very same.
Evelyn? How in Kasterborous did you know that?
(laughs) Read the bill board outside, I should imagine.
This is Ford's Theatre, Doctor. Washington DC, 1865.
It's collapsible, right? Damned if I can find the switch.
Don't do that. Ford's Theatre?
Correct.
Washington DC?
Precisely.
On the nose.
Then you must be John Thompson Ford?
No.
Oh.
Henry Clay Ford, his brother.
The house treasurer, yes?
I've got my sights on higher things.
Doctor, this isn't good.
Evelyn, I very much doubt we'd have been so unlucky as to have landed at precisely
Mister Ford, I wonder if you could furnish us with today's date.
Eh?
The date. We've only just arrived, and the time difference can be a little confusing.
Oh, sure, sure, sure. It's April 14th.
This Oscar Wilde. I want to see him. Now.
Door opens, wolf whistle.
Well now, Thomas, lookee here. Ain't it the grandest thing?
Just a peek, Lizzie, that's all I said.
And that's all I'm taking. A peek don't mean a glance, after all?
Lizzie.
Shut the door if you don't want to get into trouble. Imagine, little old me in the Blue Room of the White House. My Daddy would have never believed it.
Oh Lizzie, you're impossible.
I think you like it. The danger, the excitement, just thinking that any moment now the President could walk in on us. Whatever would he say?
I haven't got long, you know.
I bet he wouldn't say that.
No, I mean
All right, Thomas Eckert, you win. Just so long as you take me out tonight.
Oh, I can't, not tonight. Mister Stanton, he'd have my guts for
Shh, don't be silly, sugar. Why shouldn't you have some time off? Who'll be any the wiser?
Lizzie, no.
Say you go down with something. You could write a note.
I'm not a well man, it's true.
Poor baby. Come, dear Lizzie. She's got just the medicine you need.
Kissing. Door opens.
Oh! Major Eckert!
Miss Harris! I
Oh, I can scare believe my eyes.
Relax, sister. Me and the Major just fancied a little sit down, that's all.
Major Eckert? Who is this creature?
I can explain, Miss Harris. Really, I can.
Oh, you'll explain all right, to the President of the United States. To Abraham Lincoln himself!
Of course, Mister Wilde is going to be appearing himself, seeing as he's a fine actor in his own right. Is it true his Prospero was praised by your own Queen Victoria?
I dare say that's what he told you, yes.
And his Bottom, a marvel to behold apparently.
Predictable.
I've never seen him work, of course, but you can't argue with the notices. Oh, we turn left here.
(sotto) I don't suppose it could be the real Oscar Wilde, could it, Doctor? You're not going to tell me he was a time traveller too.
It wasn't in the programme notes when I saw the opening night of Ernest, thirty years from now.
Hmm, thought not. Besides, what would he travel around in? A handbag?
No, no, no. Abraham Lincoln is assassinated here, tonight, at Ford's Theatre. There's more to this, and I mean to find out what it is. Come on.
Is it much further, Mister Ford?
Regular rabbit warren, ain't it? Lost a bear dancing act down here once. Pops, he reckons they're still here. Says that every now and again he hears this weird and unearthly growl.
Oh, fascinating.
Oh, just this way. Say, if you're a real doctor, could you take a look at my neck? It hurts every time I do this.
Well, don't do that, then.
He's not strictly a medical man, Mister Ford.

Oh, right. Some kind of affectation for the stage? I've heard about your English music hall, of course, but quite frankly, fat women singing songs about almost getting married won't cut the mustard with an American audience. We like our entertainment a little more sophisticated, if you know what I mean. Ah, here we are. (knocks) Mister Wilde? Mister Wilde? I guess he's resting.
I don't care if he never works again.
Hey!
Opens door.
Wilde? Wilde! Oh.
Empty. Oh, what a pong!
The air does seem a little heavy.
We must have missed him.
Interesting cabinet. Warm.
Kinda like your blue box.
Kinda. A magician's vanishing box. Reminds me of Chung Ling Soo's.
Chung Ling who's?
A marvellous Chinese conjurer. Did the old bullet catching trick. Saw him do it for the last time, in fact.
Don't tell me, the bullet caught him.
The Wood Green Empire, 1918.
We have to find this Wilde, and quickly. Where is he, Mister Ford?
I don't have to be telling you nothing.
It's important, man! Where else would he be?
Last I knew, old Johnny Booth was coming down to read for him.
John Wilkes Booth?
How many Johnny Booths do you know in this city?
This is bad. This is very, very bad.
Look, I don't know who you think
I think it's time we told him who we really are.
Evelyn, don't make it any worse.
Mister Ford, we never sleep.
(gasp) Pinkerton! You're with the Pinkertons. Well, why didn't you say? Of course, you couldn't. Two real life Pinkerton men, here in my theatre. So, how can I assist?
We need to find Wilde.
He might be reading with Booth, on stage I guess. There's more than one way up.
Evelyn, wait here with Ford. Don't let him out of your sight.
What are you going to do?
Explain later.
So, what's this all about? Is Wilde in trouble?
He will be, when the Doctor finds him.
Hey, he left a couple of glasses behind. I don't mind telling you, I can do with a drink.
Be my guest, Mister Ford.
Major Eckert, this is the White House. You have a position of trust here. How dare you abuse it?
Miss Harris, please.
Oh, where's the harm? He was just showing me around. Loosen your corset, will ya?
Major Eckert, would you please remove your friend.
I got as much right to be here as you do.
Oh, I, my dear, am the daughter of a Senator. You clearly are the daughter of the gutter.
Lizzie, wait outside.
I was already going. Good day, ma'am. Oh, and Thomas, you won't forget your promise, will ya?
Door closes.
Thomas, what in God's name were you thinking?
Miss Harris, Clara, please. This was a moment of madness.
There's madness everywhere today. This rally this morning, it turned nasty. I swear I even heard voices calling for the President's blood.
The President is safe, surrounded by good men and true, believe me.
I wish I could. But when you can't even trust the police
The police?
Fellow named Parker in the crowd, not bothering himself unduly. And then I returned to find you, Thomas, cavorting with some jade, oh, in Blue Room.
Perhaps I'd better escort her out. You won't, you won't tell Stanton, will you?
I don't know. Trust is a fickle thing, Major Eckert. Once lost, it takes a lot to get it back.
I understand.
Well? My name is Ernest in town and Jack in the country, and the cigarette case was given to me in the country.
Perhaps a fraction less guttersnipe, Mister Booth.
(Dick Van Dyke-esque) More like this?
Let's plough on. Top of the next page.
My dear Algie.
That's it.
My dear Algie, I don't know whether you'll be able to understand my real motives. You're hardly serious enough. When one is placed in the position of guardian
One has to adopt a very high moral tone on all subjects.
Oh no. Doctor.
Doctor Robert Knox, formerly of Edinburgh.
What's he talking about, Wilde?
Take five, dear boy.
Five what?
Minutes. We have a critic in the house.
Sir. (leaves)
Now Doctor, I do hope you'll not be adopting a high moral tone.
Oh zip it, Knox, or Wilde, or whatever you're currently calling yourself.
Knox will do. I grew rather attached to the name, as a matter of fact.
So they haven't caught up with you yet.

That's the beauty of owning a Tardis, isn't it? You can always stay one step ahead, or behind. Oh, I er put in the odd appearance now and then, just to show my face, drop off a couple of articles for the newspaper. Perhaps something larger for my publisher. You know my books on fishing are proving extremely popular. Of course, in this day and age, the play's the thing.
Business is good, then.

Oh, flourishing. There's fantastic money to be made out of the legitimate theatre, particularly when the whole of Earth's future is mine to plunder. Wilde, Beckett, Orton, Pinter. I can pour myself a bowlful of greatness at the merest flick of a switch.
Is that what you've become, a temporal plagiarist?
Literary criticism is not your forte, my dear fellow. Don't try it.
Get on with it, Wilde. I haven't got all day.
Why, what else have you got planned, Mister Booth? Busy day ahead?
I don't care for your tone, sir.
Careful, Doctor. Mister Booth is a man of passion.
Isn't he just.
Well, sir? Out with it?
As you were. I'm watching you, Knox. Perhaps you'd allow me to watch you rehearse? I'm a great fan of Mister Wilde's work.
Very well, but don't interrupt. From when one is placed?
Why not?
When one is placed in the position of guardian, one has to adopt a very high moral tone on all subjects. It's ones (struggling to speak) duty to
What's the matter with him? Knox?
I haven't a clue.
Stop! Stop!
Ah, Doctor Smythe. Such an expected pleasure.
You!
I'm sorry, Mister Wilde. I couldn't stop her.
There's poison, Doctor.
Poison?
In the elderberry cordial, in Knox's dressing room. I mean, I can't be sure, but I'm always suspicious of elderberries which smell of almonds.
P-p-poison? Wilde, you (coughs, thud)
Booth? Mister Booth!
Oh no.
Changing history again, are we, Knox?
Booth, come on. Booth!
KNOx: Too late, I fear, Mister Ford.
This man is dead!
Now please don't agitate yourself. He was a dreadful actor in any case.
Dead, in Ford's Theatre!
Doctor, if Booth's dead, who's going to kill the President?
Who indeed.

FORD: I guess it must be the latest thing in London, right? Just like you, Mister Wilde.

FORD: Well, welcome to my theatre.
KNOX: Your brother's theatre, I believe?

KNOX: I was a little early. Your boy, Pops, showed me in here and made me very comfortable. He even made me tea, or some Atlantic variation thereof.

KNOX: How distressing for you. (yawns) I wonder whether you'd mind
FORD: Oh, of course, of course. You're tired. I'm so sorry, Mister Wilde. I guess I'll leave you to it. You've had one heck of a journey, I expect.
KNOX: You've no idea.

EVELYN: Oh, cricket. How did we get on to cricket?
DOCTOR: Ah ha! One moment. Percy George, you see. He was one of the true gentlemen of the game. There, that should do it.
EVELYN: Do what?
DOCTOR: This.
EVELYN: Oh, scientific as ever, Doctor.

FORD: Henry. Mister Booth, sir. The big man, he's in Richmond.
BOOTH: Don't matter, junior. Where's Maisie?
FORD: Maisie?
BOOTH: Titian haired beauty, runs the box office.
FORD: Oh, she's off. Stomach cramps or something.

BOOTH: Curious atmosphere here.

BOOTH: What's in here?
KNOX: My cabinet of curiosities.
BOOTH: Your what?
KNOX: Curios. The clue's in the name. Mister Booth, you seem edgy.
BOOTH: These are strange days we're living through.
KNOX: Ah yes, and a man of your sympathies needs to be careful, yes?
BOOTH: What do you know of my sympathies, sir? Speak, or let Mister Bowie's blade paint these walls in English rouge.
KNOX: I was, I was referring to those platonic sympathies common in the brotherhood of actors, but tragically misunderstood in the wider world.
BOOTH: Wilde, I thought you knew my reputation. Bad Johnny Booth only has eyes for the ladies. My knife ain't for no fruit.
KNOX: Speaking of fruit, would you care for a glass of elderberry cordial? A trifle tart on the tongue, but positively bursting with antioxidants.
BOOTH: Well, if you're imbibing yourself.
KNOX: Bums up. Hmm, sublime. Drink, drink.
BOOTH: In a moment. Business first.
KNOX: Of course. I'll come straight to the point, Mister Booth. I saw you last year in Boston.
BOOTH: Highlights from Shakespeare.
KNOX: Indeed. That night I Knew I'd seen the finest actor on the American stage, a figure to rival any in the opposite continent. Keen, Beerbohm Tree, Olivier.
BOOTH: Olivier?
KNOX: Perhaps I'm being a trifle previous. No matter. You get my gist? These are princes, my boy, proud princes. Some actors are little better than strolling psychopaths, but it comes to a very few to be great. And you, Mister Booth, you will walk amongst them.
BOOTH: You think so.
KNOX: I know so. And that is why I've written a little piece with you in mind. Booth?
BOOTH: (sotto) I thought I heard something behind that curtain.
KNOX: Behind the curtain? Are you sure? I don't see anything.
BOOTH: Made you look, though, didn't I?
KNOX: Very convincing.
BOOTH: Mud in your eye, Wilde. Hmm, not bad. This piece, is it tragedy, comedy, what?
KNOX: Comedy of a kind. The hero of the piece is a smart young man who calls himself Jack, but thinks himself Ernest.
FORD: (gasp) Burglars! Burglars and vagabonds.
EVELYN: Well, really. Do we look the type?
FORD: Well, if it's last night's takings your after, I've banked them already.
DOCTOR: No, you haven't.
FORD: Hands off, Captain.
DOCTOR: Doctor, actually. And believe it or not, we've no interest in your takings.
FORD: Hold up. Is that an English accent?
DOCTOR: To your ears, maybe.
FORD: Of course! You're with him.
EVELYN: Him?
FORD: I don't Know why I didn't see it before. I thought Mister Wilde was dandy enough, but this fellow here, he takes the biscuit, eh, lady?
DOCTOR: I beg your pardon?
FORD: Well, that coat may be all the thing in Piccadilly, son, but here in DC folks will take you for a theatrical.
DOCTOR: Now look here.
FORD: Of course, that's exactly what you are, isn't it. Seeing as you're with Oscar Wilde.
DOCTOR: Just because a person happens. Did he just say Oscar Wilde?
EVELYN: He did.
FORD: So, what's in the box, eh, Doc? More fancy costumes?
DOCTOR: Er, yes, among other things. Evelyn, this is 1865. Oscar Wilde's not out of short trousers.
EVELYN: Yes, yes, obviously, but
DOCTOR: Something's very wrong here. I can smell it.
FORD: Damn, but this thing's warm. How'd you get this through the door?
DOCTOR: Oh, secrets of the trade, Mister er
EVELYN: Ford, isn't it?
FORD: The very same.
DOCTOR: Evelyn? How in Kasterborous did you know that?
FORD: (laughs) Read the bill board outside, I should imagine.
EVELYN: This is Ford's Theatre, Doctor. Washington DC, 1865.
FORD: It's collapsible, right? Damned if I can find the switch.
DOCTOR: Don't do that. Ford's Theatre?
EVELYN: Correct.
DOCTOR: Washington DC?
EVELYN: Precisely.
DOCTOR: 1865?
EVELYN: On the nose.
DOCTOR: Then you must be John Thompson Ford?
FORD: No.
DOCTOR: Oh.
FORD: Henry Clay Ford, his brother.
EVELYN: The house treasurer, yes?
FORD: I've got my sights on higher things.
EVELYN: Doctor, this isn't good.
DOCTOR: Evelyn, I very much doubt we'd have been so unlucky as to have landed at precisely
EVELYN: Mister Ford, I wonder if you could furnish us with today's date.
FORD: Eh?
EVELYN: The date. We've only just arrived, and the time difference can be a little confusing.
FORD: Oh, sure, sure, sure. It's April 14th.
DOCTOR: This Oscar Wilde. I want to see him. Now.
LIZZIE: Well now, Thomas, lookee here. Ain't it the grandest thing?
ECKERT: Just a peek, Lizzie, that's all I said.
LIZZIE: And that's all I'm taking. A peek don't mean a glance, after all?
ECKERT: Lizzie.
LIZZIE: Shut the door if you don't want to get into trouble. Imagine, little old me in the Blue Room of the White House. My Daddy would have never believed it.
ECKERT: Oh Lizzie, you're impossible.
LIZZIE: I think you like it. The danger, the excitement, just thinking that any moment now the President could walk in on us. Whatever would he say?
ECKERT: I haven't got long, you know.
LIZZIE: I bet he wouldn't say that.
ECKERT: No, I mean
LIZZIE: All right, Thomas Eckert, you win. Just so long as you take me out tonight.
ECKERT: Oh, I can't, not tonight. Mister Stanton, he'd have my guts for
LIZZIE: Shh, don't be silly, sugar. Why shouldn't you have some time off? Who'll be any the wiser?
ECKERT: Lizzie, no.
LIZZIE: Say you go down with something. You could write a note.
ECKERT: I'm not a well man, it's true.
LIZZIE: Poor baby. Come, dear Lizzie. She's got just the medicine you need.
CLARA: Oh! Major Eckert!
ECKERT: Miss Harris! I
CLARA: Oh, I can scare believe my eyes.
LIZZIE: Relax, sister. Me and the Major just fancied a little sit down, that's all.
CLARA: Major Eckert? Who is this creature?
ECKERT: I can explain, Miss Harris. Really, I can.
CLARA: Oh, you'll explain all right, to the President of the United States. To Abraham Lincoln himself!
FORD: Of course, Mister Wilde is going to be appearing himself, seeing as he's a fine actor in his own right. Is it true his Prospero was praised by your own Queen Victoria?
DOCTOR: I dare say that's what he told you, yes.
FORD: And his Bottom, a marvel to behold apparently.
DOCTOR: Predictable.
FORD: I've never seen him work, of course, but you can't argue with the notices. Oh, we turn left here.
EVELYN: (sotto) I don't suppose it could be the real Oscar Wilde, could it, Doctor? You're not going to tell me he was a time traveller too.
DOCTOR: It wasn't in the programme notes when I saw the opening night of Ernest, thirty years from now.
EVELYN: Hmm, thought not. Besides, what would he travel around in? A handbag?
DOCTOR: No, no, no. Abraham Lincoln is assassinated here, tonight, at Ford's Theatre. There's more to this, and I mean to find out what it is. Come on.
EVELYN: Is it much further, Mister Ford?
FORD: Regular rabbit warren, ain't it? Lost a bear dancing act down here once. Pops, he reckons they're still here. Says that every now and again he hears this weird and unearthly growl.
DOCTOR: Oh, fascinating.
FORD: Oh, just this way. Say, if you're a real doctor, could you take a look at my neck? It hurts every time I do this.
DOCTOR: Well, don't do that, then.
EVELYN: He's not strictly a medical man, Mister Ford.
FORD: Oh, right. Some kind of affectation for the stage? I've heard about your English music hall, of course, but quite frankly, fat women singing songs about almost getting married won't cut the mustard with an American audience. We like our entertainment a little more sophisticated, if you know what I mean. Ah, here we are. (knocks) Mister Wilde? Mister Wilde? I guess he's resting.
DOCTOR: I don't care if he never works again.
FORD: Hey!
DOCTOR: Wilde? Wilde! Oh.
EVELYN: Empty. Oh, what a pong!
DOCTOR: The air does seem a little heavy.
FORD: We must have missed him.
DOCTOR: Interesting cabinet. Warm.
FORD: Kinda like your blue box.
DOCTOR: Kinda. A magician's vanishing box. Reminds me of Chung Ling Soo's.
EVELYN: Chung Ling who's?
DOCTOR: A marvellous Chinese conjurer. Did the old bullet catching trick. Saw him do it for the last time, in fact.
EVELYN: Don't tell me, the bullet caught him.
DOCTOR: The Wood Green Empire, 1918.
FORD: 1918?
DOCTOR: We have to find this Wilde, and quickly. Where is he, Mister Ford?
FORD: I don't have to be telling you nothing.
DOCTOR: It's important, man! Where else would he be?
FORD: Last I knew, old Johnny Booth was coming down to read for him.
EVELYN: John Wilkes Booth?
FORD: How many Johnny Booths do you know in this city?
DOCTOR: This is bad. This is very, very bad.
FORD: Look, I don't know who you think
EVELYN: I think it's time we told him who we really are.
DOCTOR: Evelyn, don't make it any worse.
EVELYN: Mister Ford, we never sleep.
FORD: (gasp) Pinkerton! You're with the Pinkertons. Well, why didn't you say? Of course, you couldn't. Two real life Pinkerton men, here in my theatre. So, how can I assist?
DOCTOR: We need to find Wilde.
FORD: He might be reading with Booth, on stage I guess. There's more than one way up.
DOCTOR: Evelyn, wait here with Ford. Don't let him out of your sight.
EVELYN: What are you going to do?
DOCTOR: Explain later.
FORD: So, what's this all about? Is Wilde in trouble?
EVELYN: He will be, when the Doctor finds him.
FORD: Hey, he left a couple of glasses behind. I don't mind telling you, I can do with a drink.
EVELYN: Be my guest, Mister Ford.
CLARA: Major Eckert, this is the White House. You have a position of trust here. How dare you abuse it?
ECKERT: Miss Harris, please.
LIZZIE: Oh, where's the harm? He was just showing me around. Loosen your corset, will ya?
CLARA: Major Eckert, would you please remove your friend.
LIZZIE: I got as much right to be here as you do.
CLARA: Oh, I, my dear, am the daughter of a Senator. You clearly are the daughter of the gutter.
ECKERT: Lizzie, wait outside.
LIZZIE: I was already going. Good day, ma'am. Oh, and Thomas, you won't forget your promise, will ya?
CLARA: Thomas, what in God's name were you thinking?
ECKERT: Miss Harris, Clara, please. This was a moment of madness.
CLARA: There's madness everywhere today. This rally this morning, it turned nasty. I swear I even heard voices calling for the President's blood.
ECKERT: The President is safe, surrounded by good men and true, believe me.
CLARA: I wish I could. But when you can't even trust the police
ECKERT: The police?
CLARA: Fellow named Parker in the crowd, not bothering himself unduly. And then I returned to find you, Thomas, cavorting with some jade, oh, in Blue Room.
ECKERT: Perhaps I'd better escort her out. You won't, you won't tell Stanton, will you?
CLARA: I don't know. Trust is a fickle thing, Major Eckert. Once lost, it takes a lot to get it back.
ECKERT: I understand.
BOOTH: Well? My name is Ernest in town and Jack in the country, and the cigarette case was given to me in the country.
KNOX: Perhaps a fraction less guttersnipe, Mister Booth.
BOOTH: (Dick Van Dyke-esque) More like this?
KNOX: Let's plough on. Top of the next page.
BOOTH: My dear Algie.
KNOX: That's it.
BOOTH: My dear Algie, I don't know whether you'll be able to understand my real motives. You're hardly serious enough. When one is placed in the position of guardian
DOCTOR: One has to adopt a very high moral tone on all subjects.
KNOX: Oh no. Doctor.
DOCTOR: Doctor Robert Knox, formerly of Edinburgh.
BOOTH: What's he talking about, Wilde?
KNOX: Take five, dear boy.
BOOTH: Five what?
KNOX: Minutes. We have a critic in the house.
BOOTH: Sir. (leaves)
KNOX: Now Doctor, I do hope you'll not be adopting a high moral tone.
DOCTOR: Oh zip it, Knox, or Wilde, or whatever you're currently calling yourself.
KNOX: Knox will do. I grew rather attached to the name, as a matter of fact.
DOCTOR: So they haven't caught up with you yet.
KNOX: That's the beauty of owning a Tardis, isn't it? You can always stay one step ahead, or behind. Oh, I er put in the odd appearance now and then, just to show my face, drop off a couple of articles for the newspaper. Perhaps something larger for my publisher. You know my books on fishing are proving extremely popular. Of course, in this day and age, the play's the thing.
DOCTOR: Business is good, then.
KNOX: Oh, flourishing. There's fantastic money to be made out of the legitimate theatre, particularly when the whole of Earth's future is mine to plunder. Wilde, Beckett, Orton, Pinter. I can pour myself a bowlful of greatness at the merest flick of a switch.
DOCTOR: Is that what you've become, a temporal plagiarist?
KNOX: Literary criticism is not your forte, my dear fellow. Don't try it.
BOOTH: Get on with it, Wilde. I haven't got all day.
DOCTOR: Why, what else have you got planned, Mister Booth? Busy day ahead?
BOOTH: I don't care for your tone, sir.
KNOX: Careful, Doctor. Mister Booth is a man of passion.
DOCTOR: Isn't he just.
BOOTH: Well, sir? Out with it?
DOCTOR: As you were. I'm watching you, Knox. Perhaps you'd allow me to watch you rehearse? I'm a great fan of Mister Wilde's work.
BOOTH: Very well, but don't interrupt. From when one is placed?
KNOX: Why not?
BOOTH: When one is placed in the position of guardian, one has to adopt a very high moral tone on all subjects. It's ones (struggling to speak) duty to
DOCTOR: What's the matter with him? Knox?
KNOX: I haven't a clue.
EVELYN: Stop! Stop!
KNOX: Ah, Doctor Smythe. Such an expected pleasure.
EVELYN: You!
FORD: I'm sorry, Mister Wilde. I couldn't stop her.
EVELYN: There's poison, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Poison?
EVELYN: In the elderberry cordial, in Knox's dressing room. I mean, I can't be sure, but I'm always suspicious of elderberries which smell of almonds.
BOOTH: P-p-poison? Wilde, you (coughs, thud)
FORD: Booth? Mister Booth!
EVELYN: Oh no.
DOCTOR: Changing history again, are we, Knox?
FORD: Booth, come on. Booth!
FORD: KNOx: Too late, I fear, Mister Ford.
FORD: This man is dead!
KNOX: Now please don't agitate yourself. He was a dreadful actor in any case.
FORD: Dead, in Ford's Theatre!
EVELYN: Doctor, if Booth's dead, who's going to kill the President?
DOCTOR: Who indeed.

elements.text: [Part Two]
This is murder.
And this article is responsible.
Not so.
But the poison.
Who's to say it wasn't meant for me? What if old man Grover got wind of my arrival? He's a formidably jealous theatrical rival.
You really expect us to believe that?
I've nothing to hide. Mister Ford? Call the police.
The police? Are you mad? General Grant is coming tonight.
And the President.
Dammit, Wilde, we can't afford to get wrapped up in scandal.
Mister Ford, a man is dead. Presidential visit or no, something must be done.
I'll tell the police. I will. Tomorrow. In the meantime (effort) you gotta help me move the body. Oh, come on, Wilde. You wouldn't want to see me ruined?
Of course I wouldn't, but it's my back. An old war wound.
Oh yeah, Waterloo, was it?
The Charge of the Light Brigade. My bayonet snagged in my new cardigan. I fell off my horse.
Pops! Pops, you gotta help me! Pops!
This has to stop, Knox.
What? I've done nothing.
You call murder nothing?
With Booth dead, Time's equilibrium is irretrievably upset.
I Know. Lincoln will live.
And what do you get out of that?

Well, Lincoln is rather good value, you know. Have you met him yet? Lovely chap. So articulate, for an American. Once his term is over, I've got great plans. Lecture tours all over Europe and the East.
With you on ten percent.
The Gettysburg Address, oh, that's a cracker. Goes down a storm. Of course, he'll need some new material.
Oh, Lincoln's we shall fight them on the beaches?
Lincoln's ich bin ein Berliner?
Lincoln's lonely heart's club band?
I say, that's rather good.
Booth may be dead, but that doesn't mean Lincoln is safe. Time abhors this sort of thing. I promise you, Knox, right now Time is working silently to repair the damage you've done.
Dammit, Pops!
Let's just see, shall we? No joy, Mister Ford? Come on, let's try backstage. Two minds are better than one. (leaves)
Doctor.
What?
Lincoln didn't deserve to die, I know, not like that. But if he lives then the consequences for American civil rights will be catastrophic.
I told you Time won't tolerate this sort of thing. Do you really think that right now only one man in America hates Lincoln enough to want to kill him?
So Booth's death could inspire another assassin. Perhaps Ford is right to keep this from the police. The fewer witnesses there are, the less history will be disrupted.
Evelyn, once we start covering up dead bodies, we may as well go into partnership with Knox. No, my mind's made up.
And?
We call Knox's bluff. We find a policeman.
Well, you're the Time Lord.
Yes. And don't I sometimes wish I wasn't.
There I was, in the Blue Room. Can you believe it, Johnny? And in storms this stuck-up piece.
Disrespecting me, she was.
And you such a fine lady, Lizzie. (drinks) That physic hit the spot. I feel better already.
A police officer needs that much medicine, he shouldn't be on duty.
Quit it, girl. How's it stand with you and the Major? Everything set for tonight?
Of course. I promised you, didn't I?
Who was this woman?
Clara Harris.
Her, yeah. She didn't hear nothing, you're sure of that?
Sure I'm sure. Thomas and me, were just, you know, planning our evening.
Spare me the details. Give me another quart. I'm dry.
I'm out of money.
You'll just have to earn some, won't you?
Johnny
Don't you worry, girl. There'll be plenty coming from the Major when we've fronted him up. Desertion, degeneracy, he'll be bleeding dollar bills for years.
Help! Is there a policeman in here?
Aw hell.
Officer? Officer, you have to come with me. There's been a murder at Ford's Theatre.

And therefore it is with great regret that I must hand over this responsibility to a man of strength. I remain your obedient servant, Thomas Eckert. Bah. Not even convincing myself. Lizzie, the things I do for you. (writing) I fear, sir, my malady has returned with such a vengeance that it could affect my reliability in this most honourable of duties.
Murder! I said, murder! At Ford's Theatre! Oh, is no one interested in history?
They think you're promoting something, Doctor.
Promoting?
Julius Caesar, perhaps?
Oh, do I look like some street corner huckster?
Well, now you come to mention it, sir.
Doctor, this is Officer Parker, come to our aid.
The way he's swaying, Evelyn, isn't he the one in need of assistance?
He's all I could find.
What's all this about a murder? Cos if this is some kind of stage door hustle, I can book you in for a week-long engagement in the cells.
No need for that, officer. Someone's died here, on stage.
Wouldn't be the first time at Ford's.
An actor, John Wilkes Booth.
Booth? Booth? (laughs) Oh, that's a good one. He's put you up to this, right? Joking Johnny.
You know him?
Course I do. What's the scoundrel up to now?
Not much. Just sort of staring.
Evelyn. I assure you, sir, there's no joke. Your friend Booth lies stone dead inside this theatre.
Show me.
Pops! Pops! Oh, where's that boy got to?
Perhaps I poisoned him too, and sequestered the body.
That Doctor must be plumb crazy, Mister Wilde. I mean, murderer? You? Anyone can see a gentleman so refined and delicate as you has no taste for killing.
Well, quite. I must say, the sight of that poor, dead, beautiful boy, with his eyeballs rolled back and his tongue lolling out. Oh.
Whoa there. I got you.
Thank you, dear sir. I'll be all right. Just my condition.
Condition?
Touch of the vapours. The old oobie-zootiks, you understand?
Oh, what am I thinking? Wilde, you need rest. Your dressing room, it's just along here.
Oh, is it?
Distant shout.
What in Heaven's name?
Oh. It came from the stage. You'd best hurry, Mister Ford. I'll catch you up.
No, no, you just wait here, Mister Wilde. I'll be back in two shakes.
You do that, Mister Ford. You do that. (sotto) Truly some mothers do have 'em.
No, no, no!
Officer Parker, I realise you're distressed.
Distressed ain't the half of it, lady. Why, I only saw Johnny Booth this very morning. Now I ain't never gonna get back the money he owed me.
Oh. And there was me thinking Booth was your friend.
Sure he was a friend. A friend I underwrote for fifty dollars in a hand of poker just last night. Who's gonna settle Johnny Booth's debts? The Devil, that's who.
This is all very edifying, Parker, but the means by which he met his end
The suddenness, the rictus expression
All of it points to one conclusion. Murder most foul.
Now, now, that's a foolish assumption to be making, and you know it, Doctor.
Ford.
Parker. I'm sorry for your being dragged away from your duties for this unfortunate accident.
Accident? Mister Ford, a man in the prime of his life is hardly likely to drop dead rehearsing a play.
Well, the way I hear it, Booth's been burning the candle at both ends for years. It wouldn't surprise me if his heart gave out.
What about the evidence, Ford?
Poison in the elderberry cordial?
Damn it, Ford, cover Booth's face, will ya? I swear he's giving me the evils in death as in life.
Oh, I can do better than that. Mind your footing, folks.
What's he doing now?
Evelyn, back!
Trap door!
Thud.
Oh.
Oh.
There. Nice and quite down there. He won't be disturbed. Well, except for the rats.
Ford!
Now then, what's all this about the elderberry cordial?
It was poisoned.
She says.
And she is?
She is Doctor Evelyn Smythe.
Evelyn Smythe.
Of Pinkertons.
Pinkertons, huh?
Well, er, not exactly.
But you said
What my associate meant is, we're in fact
Freelance.
Freelance. So, bounty hunters, huh?
Officer Parker, surely it'd be best if we showed you the cordial in question.
The way I'm thinking, it'd be best if I showed you and your lady friend the nasty side of Tommy Truncheon.
Well, I've never heard it called that before.
You were saying, the cordial.
The elderberry cordial in the dressing room.
Booth's dressing room?
Doctor Knox's dressing room.
Doctor who?
She means Wilde.
Doctor Wilde?
No, his name's Doctor Knox. He's just posing as Wilde.
Well, we don't know his real name. It's not Knox or Wilde.
Evelyn.
Where is he, by the way?
Who?
Knox. Wilde.
Now you said
Officer, please. You can catch up later. Ford.
Wha?
+ EVELYN: Where's Wilde?
I left him in his dressing room.
With the evidence.
More to the point, with his Tardis.
Tardis?
His Chinese cabinet. You don't think?
Oh yes, I do. Come on!
Well now, reckon I'm two arrests away from being all done here. Let's get after them.
Er, Officer Parker? It can wait, can't it? Until the morning?
Well, that depends.
Excellent. Well then, let's discuss it in my office.
Lead on, junior,
Lift arrives, bell dings, door opens.
Elevator doors closing.
Scanner.
Scanner activating.
Ah, Doctor. Try again, my dear fellow. Three, two, one, heave. Oh, bang on cue.
[OC]: Where is he?
[OC]: Hidden away in his curious cabinet. Show yourself, Knox! Open up! (knocks) Open up, I say.
Oh, if you insist. Doors.
Opening doors.
[OC]: Meddler, miscreant.
Misanthrope. Murderer.
Sticks and stones may break my bones, but alliterations will never hurt me. Now you're letting a draught in. Close.
Closing doors.
Huh, voice control? You've got voice control?
KNOx: I've traded up. All the mod cons. There's even an elevator.
An elevator?!
You sound more like Lady Bracknell everyday. I'm confused. Why hasn't Knox, you know
Done a bunk already? Oh, I'm sure the Doctor will have worked that out, what with his towering intellect and all.
Well, Doctor?
His Tardis is broken.
Operational status?
Tardis functions at optimum.
Then he's staying around to guard against my interfering with his plans.
But surely with Booth dead, the damage is done.
Well, his fatal arrogance compels him to remain behind and gloat.
I don't Know about you, Doctor Smythe, but I'm far from convinced. No, the reason I'm still here is actually, well, I think it would be better if I showed you.
Oh no you don't. Hands off the console, Knox. I'm not having you lure us into some cross- dimensional trap. I wasn't born yesterday, you know.
Really, Doctor. All this fuss. We're only headed a few blocks north and west. The fact is, at my time of life I need to save my legs. Don't you trust me?
I'd sooner trust a fox to run a chicken coop.
Then why not pilot the machine yourself? It's just a small spatial displacement to Lafayette Park.
Why not pilot
Well, why not? Sounds reasonable.
I understand your reticence, Doctor. This is, after all, a rather better Tardis than you're used to, and its functions must seem rather baffling. Perhaps if I
I can manage perfectly. Give me manual control.
Manual control now in operation.
Small spatial displacement, is it? Easy peasy lemon
Sluice engaged.
That can't be right.
I, I thought it er, best to shed some ballast before take-off.
Might I suggest open flange, crank lever, and press enter?
This machine needs a service, Knox.
Hmm, don't we all.
Tardis dematerialises.
Come in, come in, Officer. Take the weight off your feet. Cigar?
Don't mind if I do. You need to be careful, Ford, leaving your office unlocked. The street scrotes are getting bolder, and I should know.
Quite.
And your money box, here for the picking. Ain't you heard of crime prevention?
Yes, yes. The thing is, Parker, I can't afford for nothing to go wrong for me today, what with General Grant due here tonight, and the President.

I appreciate your problem, Mister Ford, I do. Actors dropping dead, playwrights running wild, bounty hunters crawling around backstage. Why, if Mister and Mrs Lincoln got wind of it, chances are they'd head over to Grovers instead.
Precisely.
But if what you're proposing is I turn a blind eye to what I've seen here this morning, I'm afraid I can't oblige.
You can't?
I've got to account for my movements, you see, and if my Sergeant asks me what I was doing at Ford's this morning, I've got to give him an answer.
Sure. Sure, sure, you have. I understand.
Terribly bold, those street scrotes are. (rustle of paper) In and out in a flash with a full night's takings.
Oh? Ah.
Personally, I'd lynch 'em. Let ‘em dangle as an example, like.
Officer Parker, it seems that, it seems as though all last night's takings have gone.
Have they now?
In an instant.
Ah, those rotten scrotes. You know, Mister Ford, fact is, when they've tried something once, they'll try it again.
Again?
Wouldn't be surprised if I had to come back here tomorrow morning to find your box office thieved once more.
Oh.
And if I should happen to find a dead actor lying here, well, I'd think those scrotes had been disturbed, wouldn't you?
I, I suppose I would.
I'll be seeing you in the morning, then.
You will.
Oh, and Ford?
What?
Be sure you get another box of those cigars in.
Tardis materialises. A horse is startled. Tardis door opens.
A bush?
Well, we are in a park. It's perfectly reasonable.
A less thorny one would have been reasonable.
Speaking of your chameleon circuit, Knox, hmm? Chung Lin Soo's cabinet?
Down to the last bullet hole. Here we are, Lafayette Park. The White House due south.
And a military encampment east.
There's been a war, you know.
I know.
But that needn't detain us. Now, onward, my friends.
We're not really going to humour this monster, are we, Doctor?
I don't see we've any choice. Booth may be dead, but the effect of his absence won't hit history for another ten hours or so. Until then, Time is in flux.
So things can be changed back?
Things can be rearranged, maybe, but first I need to know what Knox is really up to.
He's after Lincoln. He said so himself.
Oh, Evelyn, you didn't really believe that, did you? No, Knox will have a bigger plot in mind.
Why Lincoln, I wonder? Why not Garfield, or McKinley, or Kennedy? He'd be the biggest draw of the lot.
Do hurry up, you two.
Come on, Doctor Smythe. Our nemesis is getting impatient.
What's keeping her?
We waiting for something, Knox?
For someone, but she's late. I don't understand it. She's usually punctual as anything. Twelve o'clock on the dot. Ah, there she is.
She rides well. Who is she?
An angel of mercy, Doctor Smythe. Miss Harris. Miss Harris!
Whoa. Whoa, whoa, whoa there. (dismounts) Mister Wilde, a pleasure to see you again.
Oscar, please. I feared our avian friends might be disappointed today.
I was slightly detained, Mister Wilde. (sotto) Government business.
Miss Harris, I take it? Miss Clara Harris?
Yes, ma'am. Do I know you?
Evelyn? What is it?
Miss Harris, allow me to introduce two of my fellow compatriots.
A pleasure, Miss Harris.
Theatricals, it is?
Doctors, actually. This one being Evelyn Smythe.
Then I am delighted to make your acquaintances, Doctors. Oh, forgive me, Mister Wilde, I don't have long today. Would you mind helping me with these sacks?
I would be honoured.
That war wound soon healed.
Surely your horse doesn't need all this, Miss Harris?
It's for the birds, sir. Thank you, Mister Wilde.

Miss Harris is a great friend to the creatures of the park. Every day at twelve o'clock she hies away with scraps from last night's White House table. She's famous for it. Of course, the soldiers camped here love her too. As soon as she's gone, it's open season. There's many a wren and a grebe ends up in a hungry squaddie's pot, all thanks to Miss Harris.
What's all this about, Knox?
You see
(returning) That's all, that's all there is.
All done for today?
Oh, alas, yes. I must away, Mister Wilde. A pity I cannot dally with you and your (sotto) theatrical friends.
Tomorrow, then?
Tomorrow, yes. Away, away.
Canters off.
Isn't she the most charming creature?
Clara Harris, daughter to a Senator.
Breeding will out.
And chief witness to the crime that's meant to unfold tonight.
So that's it.

She knows her stuff, Doctor. Late this afternoon General and Mrs Grant will cancel their engagement and take the night train to Burlington. Mister and Mrs Lincoln will invite Miss Harris and her fiancé Major Rathbone in their stead.
That was when I first saw her, wrapped in a Morris shawl, in the box at Ford's. The Major to her right, Mrs Lincoln to her left. All of them leaning forward over the rail to hear Harry Hawk's patter.
Don't know the manners of good society, eh? Well, I guess I Know enough to turn you inside
out, old gal. You sockdologising old mantrap.

That's when Booth made his entrance. No hogging the limelight for him. He was too good an actor for that. Hawk's laugh, the one he knew was coming, that was his cue. He stepped into the box from the rear, said very quietly
Mister President
And fired! And I promise you, this is the truth. At the very moment his Derringer discharged I, oh, I'm ashamed to admit it.
+ EVELYN: What?
Well, as you know, a while back I caught something of a cold. All sorted out now, but in the very instant Booth's pistol cracked.
(sneeze!) I do beg your pardon.
Well now, when I think what I've thrown away in hard cash today, I'd have to call myself some awful hard names. Four hundred thousand dollars is a big pile for a man to light his cigar with.

But something was happening off to Hawk's right. The Major reacted, but Booth was on him at once, with his Bowie knife. Oh, I've seen it up close. It's a terror. Miss Harris turned then, her lovely mouth open for what seemed like forever before the sound came out.
Clara screams. Audience gasps.
And then there Booth was, vaulting the rail, stood for a moment in full view of all and crying out loud
Sic semper tyrannis!
Or was it
The South shall be avenged!
I was so caught up in it all, I can't seem to remember. He landed on stage and darted past Hawk, fled into the wings. Finally it was Miss Harris' moment.
Stop that man! Will no one stop that man! He has shot the President!
The comedy turned to tragedy. The greatest night of Miss Harris' life turned into the worst. Her becoming blue dress became reddened in the Major's arterial blood.
Oh, that's enough, Knox.

It's not the worst of it, though. The Major recovers, physically at least, but the night's madness never leave him. Twenty years or so later he takes a gun and a knife, just like Booth. He shoots her, and stabs her to death.
Evelyn.
It's awful, just awful.
I know. Oh, what was Lincoln, just another here today and gone tomorrow politician, his usefulness behind him. But Clara? Oh, hardly anyone weeps for poor dead Clara.
Her life ended that night surely as Lincoln's.
Knox, answer me something. Are you in love with Miss Harris?
Gunfire.
Doctor, Miss Smythe, we should away to the theatre.
Answer me.
Come on, away. The trooper's bellies are rumbling and we seem to be in the firing line.
Answer me!
Knock on door.
Patience, sugar. Patience.
[OC]: Damn it, Lizzie, it's me.
John Parker, just cos you've had a skin full doesn't mean you get to take liberties.
Unlocks door.
I've not got liberties in mind. Not that kind, anyway.
John, whatever's the matter?
Shut the door, girl.
I can't say I care for your tone.
Shut the damn door!
Whatever you say, sugar.
Door closes.
Booth's dead.
Johnny Booth?
Of course Johnny Booth. Heart gave out, it looks like. I went to his room hoping to get back some of the money he owed me. Spent the lot of it, curse him. But it's what else I found. Maps and
letters, plans and schemes. Read here.

(reads) For a long time I have devoted my energies to the accomplishment of a certain end. The moment has arrived, and posterity I am sure will justify me. Men who love their country better than gold and life.
And there's more, much more. The evidence is irrefutable.
What's it mean, John?
Booth was plotting to murder the President.
Oh my.
Soon, maybe even tonight. Who'd have thought a preening ham actor had so much in him?
But this is terrible.
Terrible Lincoln should escape, oh yes. But I'll tell you what, Lizzie. Old Booth's gonna have his day after all. How's your Major Eckert?
Thomas? He's fine, I guess.
I need him here. Within the hour.
The hour? I could send him a note.
You do that. I've got a plan, Lizzie, but there's only three things stood in my way. The playwright Wilde and the two people he's associated with. A man and a woman, doctors they are, bounty hunters.
What do you mean?
They gotta die, now, this afternoon, and your Major Eckert's gonna be their assassin.
